The Buddha was in the country of Vá¹›ji, also known as the country of ÅšrÄvastÄ«, or alternatively as the country of ÅšrÄvastÄ«.

At that time, the Buddha sat and practiced Ä€nÄpÄna-smá¹›ti for ninety days. The Buddha then sat alone for another ninety days, contemplating and calculating, wishing to liberate the people of the ten directions, as well as the wriggling and flying creatures.
He further said, I practiced Ä€nÄpÄna-smá¹›ti for ninety days. By practicing Ä€nÄpÄna-smá¹›ti, I attained the mind of self-mastery and compassion;
After practicing Ä€nÄpÄna-smá¹›ti again, I collected my mind and practiced mindfulness.
Ä€nÄ refers to the body, pÄna refers to the breath, and smá¹›ti refers to the Way.
Smá¹›ti means to restrain, and also means not to violate the precepts;
Restraint also means to protect;
Protection means to protect everything without transgression.
Mind means to control the mind, which is also the Way.
An means birth, pan means cessation, intention is the cause and condition, and guarding is the Way.
An means counting, pan means following, and guarding the mind is stopping.ğŸ”½An means remembering the Way, pan means unknotting, and guarding the mind means not falling into offenses.
An means avoiding offenses, pan means not entering offenses, and guarding the mind is the Way.
An means concentration, pan means not allowing movement, and guarding the mind means not disturbing the mind.
AnÄpÄna-smá¹›ti is called controlling the mind to attain the unconditioned.
An means existence, pan means non-existence.
If the mind thinks of existence, one cannot attain the Way;
if the mind thinks of non-existence, one cannot attain the Way;
neither thinking of existence nor thinking of non-existence, this corresponds to the emptiness concentration, and the mind follows the practice of the Way.
Existence refers to myriad things, non-existence refers to doubt, which is also emptiness.
An is the original cause and condition, pan is the absence of a location.
The practitioner knows that the mind originally comes from nowhere, and also knows that when it ceases, there is no place it goes to. This is guarding the mind.
An means tranquility, pan means purity, shou means non-existence, and yi means mind. This is tranquility, purity, and non-existence.
Wu means alive, wei means born. Not experiencing suffering again is called being alive.
An means not yet, pan means arising.
If it has not yet arisen, then it is guarding the mind;
If the mind has already arisen, then it is guarding the mind;
If the mind has already arisen and runs away, it is not being guarded. It should be brought back. Therefore, the Buddha taught anpan shouyi.
An means receiving the five aggregates, pan means eliminating the five aggregates. Guarding the mind means being aware of causes and conditions, and not following body, speech, or mind.
Guarding the mind means having no attachments, which is guarding the mind. Having attachments is not guarding the mind.
Why is it so?
Because the mind arises and then ceases.
The mind not arising again is the way. This is guarding the mind.
Guard the mind and do not let the mind arise. Arising causes death. This is not guarding the mind.
Do not let the mind die. Death causes arising. The mind also does not die. This is the Way.

Ä€nÄpÄnasmá¹›ti has ten kinds of wisdom, namely counting the breath, following, stopping, contemplating, returning, and the four noble truths. These are the ten kinds of wisdom. Accomplishment means combining the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment to achieve practice.
Guarding the mind is like a lamp. There are two causes and conditions:
First, dispelling darkness;
Second, seeing brightness.
Guarding the mind:
First, dispelling delusion;
Second, seeing wisdom.
Guarding the mind, the mind arises from causes and conditions. Rely on causes and conditions, do not become attached. This is guarding the mind.
Guarding the mind has three levels:
First, guarding to prevent it from arising;
Second, having already arisen, quickly extinguish it;
Third, having already acted, repent and reflect, and do not do it again for millions of eons.

Guarding and intention are each different. Protecting and being aware of all in the ten directions without transgression is guarding. Being aware of their non-action is intention. This is guarding the mind.
There are four kinds of joy in guarding the mind:
First, the joy of knowing essentials;
Second, the joy of knowing the Dharma;
Third, the joy of knowing cessation;
Fourth, the joy of knowing what is acceptable;
These are the four joys.
The Dharma is practice, attainment is the Way.
Guarding the mind has six matters, which are internal and external:
Counting, following, and stopping are external, contemplating, returning, and purifying are internal.
It follows the Way. Why is it so?
Because mindfulness of the breath, following, stopping, contemplating, returning, and purifying are close to the Way.
Apart from these six matters, one then follows the world.

Counting the breath is to restrain the mind, following is to subdue the mind, stopping is to concentrate the mind, contemplating is to detach the mind, returning is to unify the mind, and purifying is to guard the mind.
It is because people cannot control their minds that they engage in these six things.
Why is it to count the breath?
Because the mind is disturbed.
Why is it not attained?
Because it is not recognized.
Why is dhyÄna not attained?
Because the practice of abandoning and exhausting habits is not realized.

Counting the breath is the ground, following is the plow, stopping is the yoke, contemplating is the seed, returning is the rain, and purification is the practice. These six things are in accordance with the path.

Counting the breath cuts off the external, following cuts off the internal, stopping is to stop offenses, practicing contemplation turns the mind away, not accepting the world is returning, and mindfulness of cutting off is purification.

When the mind is disturbed, one should count the breath. When the mind is concentrated, one should follow. When the mind is cut off, one should practice stopping. When the mind attains the path, one should contemplate. Not turning towards the five aggregates is returning. Being without anything is purification.

For those with many affairs, they should count the breath; for those with few affairs, they should follow the breath; for those whose minds are full of household affairs, they should practice stopping; for those who fear the world, they should contemplate; for those who do not wish to return to the world, they should recall the cessation of defilements; for those who wish to purify, they should practice purification.
Why count the breath?
Because one does not wish to follow the five aggregates.
Why follow the breath?
Because one wishes to know the five aggregates.
Why stop?
Because one wishes to contemplate the five aggregates.
Why contemplate the aggregates?
Because one wishes to know the origin of the body.
Why know the origin of the body?
Because one wishes to abandon suffering.
Why return?
Because one is disgusted with birth and death.
Why purify?
Because one does not grasp the five aggregates after discerning them.
One then follows the eightfold noble path of wisdom and attains what one wishes.

When practicing exhalation, it is following counting; when following the characteristics, it is following mindfulness; when stopping, it is following concentration; when observing, it is following purity; when returning, it is following intention; when purifying, it is following the path, and it is also following practice.

Counting the breath is the four foundations of mindfulness, following is the four right efforts, stopping is the four bases of supernatural power, observing is the five faculties and five powers, returning is the seven factors of awakening, and purifying is the eightfold path.
Obtaining the breath but not following it is not guarding the mind;ğŸ”½obtaining following but not stopping is not guarding the mind;
obtaining stopping but not observing is not guarding the mind;ğŸ”½obtaining observing but not returning is not guarding the mind;
obtaining returning but not purifying is not guarding the mind;
obtaining purifying and purifying again is guarding the mind.
Having contemplated the breath, evil does not arise, and counting again is to jointly block the mind and not follow the six sense objects.

The aspect of practice is to be free from the six deteriorations. The practice of stopping is to ward off the six deteriorations. The practice of contemplation is to cut off the six deteriorations. The practice of returning is to not accept the six deteriorations. The practice of purity is to extinguish the six deteriorations.
Having already extinguished them, one then follows the path.
Counting the breath is to restrain the mind. There are long and short breaths, and one should also restrain the thoughts of long and short.
Why is it to guard the mind?
It is to stop evil.
Evil can be guarded against, and it can also not be guarded against.
Why is this?
If evil has already been exhausted, it should not be guarded against again.
There are three things in counting the breath:
First, one should sit and practice;
Second, when seeing form, one should contemplate impermanence and impurity;
Third, one should understand anger, doubt, jealousy, and thoughts of the past.
If the breath is disordered, one should recognize the causes and conditions from which it arises, and know that this is the inner mind.
If a single breath is disordered, it is an error of the outer mind, because the breath enters from the outside;
The second, calming agitation, is an internal mental fault, as the breath comes out from within.
The third, fifth, seventh, and ninth belong to the external mind, while the fourth, sixth, eighth, and tenth belong to the internal mind.
Jealousy, anger, and doubt, these three minds are internal;
Killing, stealing, lust, slander, harsh speech, false speech, and frivolous speech, these seven minds and other matters belong to the external.
Obtaining the breath is external, not obtaining the breath is internal.
The breath arises from the mind, thinking of the breath combines into one, counting the breath to the end of counting, is one, also not one, the mind is external, the breath is not yet exhausted.
It is like counting money, the mind is on five, counting as one.
The reason for counting the breath first is that externally there are seven evils, internally there are three evils, using few cannot overcome many, so first count the inhalation.
Those who cannot count the breath lose their original intention.
The original intention refers to impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and non-self.
Losing this intention and falling into delusion is also losing the teacher.
When the teacher first sits, in the first inhalation, they attain bodily comfort and then proceed in sequence;
Because they lose the original intention, they cannot attain tranquility.
When counting the breath, the mind should always contemplate impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and non-self, and consider that the exhalation also ceases and the inhalation also ceases.
Having understood this, one will attain the Way and quickly hold the intention of fearing impermanence.
Attaining this intention is the same as attaining tranquility.
The reason for the difference between inhalation and exhalation is that exhalation is the aggregate of birth and death, and inhalation is the aggregate of thought;
Sometimes exhalation is the aggregate of pain and itchiness, and inhalation is the aggregate of consciousness.
This is the difference, and practitioners should discern this intention.
Inhalation is for not accepting offenses, exhalation is for eliminating offenses, and guarding the mind is for being free from offenses.
Inhaling is the cause of receiving, exhaling is the cause of reaching, and guarding the mind is the cause of non-separation.
There are three causes for not attaining counting of the breath:
First, the offense has arrived;
Second, the practice is not mutual;
Third, there is no diligence.
Inhaling is short, exhaling is long, not thinking of anything is the mind of the Way, thinking of something is an offense;
Offenses and evils are outside, not inside.
When counting the breath, there is a distracted mind for long breaths, and attainment of the breath for short breaths. Being unsettled in practicing the breath is long, being concentrated is short.
Thinking of myriad things is a long breath, not thinking of anything is a short breath.
Before reaching ten breaths, destroying and counting again is a long breath, attaining ten breaths is a short breath.
Attaining the breath is short, why is this?
Because one stops and does not count again.
Attaining the breath is also long, why is this?
Because the breath does not cease, it is long.
Knowing when the breath is long and when it is short:
It means knowing the length and shortness of the mind, knowing the length and shortness of the mind's awareness, and not knowing the length and shortness of the mind's non-awareness.
When a practitioner of AnÄpÄna-smá¹›ti wishes to stop the mind, what conditions are needed to stop the mind?
Listen to the explanation of AnÄpÄna-smá¹›ti. What is AnÄ?
What is Ä€pÄna?
AnÄ is called inhalation, and Ä€pÄna is called exhalation. Not being apart from mindfulness of the breath is called AnÄpÄna.
The practitioner of AnÄpÄna-smá¹›ti wishes to stop the mind.

For practitioners and beginners, there are four kinds of AnÄpÄna-smá¹›ti practice, which eliminate two evils and sixteen excellences. At that time, one should know that it is the practice of AnÄpÄna-smá¹›ti, which enables one to stop the mind.
What are the four kinds?
First, counting; second, following; third, stopping; fourth, observing.
What are the two evils?
Do not exceed ten breaths, do not reduce the number to less than ten.
What are the sixteen superiorities?ğŸ”½Immediately know for oneself if the breath is long;
Immediately know for oneself if the breath is short;ğŸ”½Immediately know for oneself if the breath moves the body;
Immediately know for oneself if the breath is subtle;ğŸ”½Immediately know for oneself if the breath is pleasant;
Immediately know for oneself if the breath is unpleasant;ğŸ”½Immediately know for oneself if the breath has stopped;
Immediately know for oneself if the breath has not stopped;ğŸ”½Immediately know for oneself if the breath brings joy to the mind;
Immediately know for oneself if the breath does not bring joy to the mind;
Immediately know for oneself that the mind has already let go of myriad things and cannot be obtained again, and the breath knows it by itself;
The mind has nothing more to think about, and the breath knows it by itself;ğŸ”½Abandoning thoughts, the breath knows it by itself;
Not abandoning thoughts, the breath knows it by itself;ğŸ”½Letting go of one's body and life, the breath knows it by itself;
Not letting go of one's body and life, the breath knows it by itself.
These are the sixteen things that one immediately knows for oneself.
Question:
What is meant by not exceeding ten counts and not reducing the number to less than ten?
The answer:
If the breath has not yet ended but you count it as having ended, this is exceeding. If the breath has not yet ended but you count it as having ended, this is reducing.
Losing count is also bad, and not keeping up is also bad, these are the two bad things.
Reaching two breaths and being confused is short breath, reaching nine breaths and being confused is long breath, attaining ten breaths is pleasant breath.
Following each other is subtle, the mind is in the long and then turns the mind:
Why do I think of the long?
The mind is in the short, and then immediately realizes that it should not let the mind stop, stopping is attachment.
Abandoning the body and life refers to practicing the breath.
Attaining the path, then one abandons the body and life;
Not yet attaining the path, always loving the body, therefore not abandoning the body and life.
The subtle breath is the path, the long is birth and death, the short breath moving is birth and death, the long in the path is short, why is it so?
Not attaining the intention of the Way, without knowledge or insight, is a deficiency.
Counting the breath is single, following is complex, stopping is single-mindedness, contemplating is knowing the mind, returning is practicing the Way, and purity is entering the Way.
When counting, it is mindfulness; reaching ten breaths is retention, which is external meditation;
mindfulness of the body's impurity following emptiness is internal meditation.
The Dharma of meditation does not accept evil coming, this is called abandoning.
Close the mouth and count the breath, following the qi coming and going, knowing where the qi arises and where it ceases.
If the mind has thoughts, one cannot count the breath;
if it is slow or fast, large or small, one also cannot count;
if hearing sounds disturbs the mind, one also cannot count.ğŸ”½Counting the breath, the mind is on the breath, counting is not skillful, the practice of the mind is in the mind, this is stopping.
Counting the breath, the mind is only on the breath, this is not skillful.
One should know that the mind arises from conditions and ceases due to conditions. This is in accordance with the method of counting, exhausting conditions, and attaining concentration.
As for guarding the mind, one contemplates the inhalation and exhalation of breath. Having contemplated the breath, one does not give rise to evil, and thus it is called guarding the mind.
The breath is seen to arise from conditions and cease due to the absence of conditions.
When the conditions are severed, the breath ceases.
Counting the breath is sincerity, and the breath not being disturbed is patience.
When counting the breath, the breath becomes subtle and one no longer feels its inhalation and exhalation. In this way, one should guard a single thought and be still.
The breath is in the body and also outside. It arises due to conditions, and because one's offenses have not yet been exhausted, there is still breath.
When the conditions are severed, the breath does not arise again.
Counting the breath is equivalent to following the second dhyÄna.
Why is this?
Because it does not depend on mindfulness, it is equivalent to following the second dhyÄna.
Counting the breath is not guarding the mind, but contemplating the breath is guarding the mind.
When exhaling from the outside, before the breath is exhausted, the breath is in the intention to inhale, in the consciousness of exhaustion, and in the counting.
Ten breaths have ten intentions, which are ten bonds. Following has two intentions, which are two bonds. Stopping is one intention, which is one bond.
Not being able to count the breath is a bad intention that cannot be bound.
When bad intentions cease, one can then count, which is a harmonious and balanced good intention to be bound.

Having attained the breath, abandon the breath. Having attained following, abandon following. Having attained stopping, abandon stopping. Having attained contemplation, abandon contemplation. Do not return.
Do not return means do not count again.
The breath also controls the mind, and the mind also controls the breath.
Having something to think about is the breath controlling the mind, having nothing to think about is the mind controlling the breath.
There are four things about the breath:
First, wind; second, qi; third, breath; fourth, panting.
Having a sound is wind, being soundless is qi. Coming in and out is breath, the qi coming in and out not being exhausted is panting.

Counting breath cuts off the external, following breath cuts off the internal. Counting from entering externally is to cut off external conditions, also wanting to leave external conditions. Counting from coming out internally is to want to leave internal conditions.
Externally is bodily separation, internally is mental separation;
bodily separation and mental separation are following, exhalation and inhalation are the two things.
Counting breath is to cut off internal and external conditions.
What are internal and external?
It refers to eyes, ears, nose, mouth, body, and mind as internal, and form, sound, smell, taste, touch, and thought as external.
Practicing breath is to make the mind turn to emptiness, just wanting to stop the remaining mind.
What is meant by turning to emptiness?
Because there is nothing to do in the breath.
Does the mind run when counting the breath?
If one immediately realizes, the sin is heavy and the mind is light. The sin pulls the mind away quickly, so one does not realize it.

Having practiced the path and attained the cessation of breath, one becomes disgusted with the mind of breath, wishing to turn away and no longer wishing to count, thus attaining the cessation of breath.
Following and stopping contemplation are also like this.
Knowing the cessation of inhalation and exhalation, cessation is the characteristic of attaining the cessation of breath;
Knowing the cycle of birth and death no longer functions, it is the characteristic of attaining the cycle of birth and death.
Having already attained the four dhyÄnas, merely contemplating emptiness is the planting of the seeds of the path.
Having practiced the breath and attained concentration, no longer aware of the inhalation and exhalation of qi, one can then contemplate.
First, one should contemplate the fifty-five matters;
Second, one should contemplate the twelve links of dependent origination in the body.
Question:
Is there a place where the inhalation and exhalation of breath does not exist?
Reply:
When the breath enters, that is its place; when the breath exits, that is its place.
Counting the breath while sitting, feelings, thoughts, birth and death, and consciousness cease and do not function, this is sitting.
Contemplating the breath and attaining the path, further calculating, is because the breath is unknowable.
Question:
How can it be said to be ignorant to attain the Way by mindfulness of breath?
Reply:
The mind knows the breath, but the breath does not know the mind. This is being ignorant.
People cannot calculate the mind, so they are made to count the breath, wanting to make the mind stable.
Although they count the breath, they do not give rise to evil.
Without wisdom, what practices should be done to attain wisdom?
From one to ten, distinguishing between stability and disturbance, recognizing and applying the medicine;
Having attained stable concentration, one then follows wisdom and attains the ability to contemplate.
Question:
What is counting?
Reply:
Counting refers to affairs.
It is like a person who has affairs and seeks more, this is called counting offenses.
The Way counts blessings, why is it precisely ten?
One thought arising is one, two thoughts arising is two, counting up to ten, reaching ten is finished, therefore it is said that ten counts are blessings.
There are also offenses. Using what cannot destroy the breath is an offense;
It is also said that the mind does not cease in birth and death, falling into the world, and not cutting off worldly affairs is an offense.
The six sense faculties are the six matters. Feeling, perception, birth and death, and consciousness, combined are the ten matters, corresponding to the inner ten breaths;
Killing, stealing, sexual misconduct, divisive speech, harsh speech, false speech, frivolous speech, envy, ill-will, and delusion, correspond to the outer ten breaths, meaning to stop and not act.
Question:
What are the sixteen matters?
Reply:

The ten matters refer to counting, up to sixteen, referring to counting, following, stopping, contemplating, returning, and purifying, these are the sixteen matters, practicing without separation, following the path.
Question:
Counting the breath and contemplating the wind follow form, why do they correspond to the path?
Reply:
The mind is focused on counting, not thinking of form. When the breath ends, it perishes, falling into impermanence. Knowing impermanence is the Way.
A practitioner who wishes to attain the Way must understand two things: sitting and walking.
First, sitting; second, walking.
Question:
Are sitting and walking the same or different?
Reply:
Sometimes the same, sometimes different.
Counting the breath, following, stopping, contemplating, returning, and purification - these six practices are sometimes sitting, sometimes walking.
Why is this?
Focusing the mind on counting the breath is sitting, following the Dharma with the mind is walking;
When the mind has arisen, not being apart from it is walking, and also sitting.
In sitting meditation, one does not count two, two does not count one.
Counting one as two means counting one breath and then saying two, this is counting one as two, this is excessive diligence;
Second, counting one means that after the breath has entered, counting two is called counting one, which is called counting one. This is not diligent enough.
From three to four, five to six, seven to eight, nine to ten, each has its own division, which should be distinguished according to its category;
counting one in one, counting two in two, this is practicing the Dharma, and then falling into diligence.
There are three kinds of sitting that fall into the Way:
one is sitting to count the breath, two is sitting to recite sutras, and three is sitting to joyfully listen to sutras, these are the three.
There are three levels of sitting:
one is sitting in union with flavor, two is pure sitting, and three is sitting without bonds.
What is sitting in union with flavor?
It means the mind is attached to practice and does not depart, this is sitting in union with flavor.
What is called pure sitting?
It means not thinking is pure sitting.
What is sitting without bonds?
It means when bonds are already exhausted, it is sitting without bonds.
There are three levels of breathing:
First, mixed breathing, second, pure breathing, third, the breathing of the Way.
Not practicing the Way is mixed breathing;
Counting to ten breaths without confusion is pure breathing;
Having attained the Way is the breathing of the Way.
Breathing has three levels:
There is great breathing, there is medium breathing, there is subtle breathing.
Speaking with the mouth is called stopping great breathing;
Contemplating the Way is stopping medium breathing;
Attaining the four dhyanas is stopping subtle breathing.
Question:
Why did the Buddha teach people to count breaths and guard the mind?
Reply:
There are four reasons:
First, because one does not desire suffering;
Second, because one avoids chaotic thoughts;
Third, because one closes off causes and conditions, not wishing to unite with birth and death;
Fourth, because one desires to attain the path of nirvana.
The parable says that the sun has no light due to four causes:
First, because there are clouds;
Second, because there is dust;
Third, because there are strong winds;
Fourth, because there is smoke.
There are also four reasons why counting the breath is ineffective:
First, because of thoughts of birth and death;
Second, because of overeating;
Third, because of exhaustion;
Fourth, because of sitting in an inauspicious place.
These four things all have signs when they come:
When sitting and counting the breath, suddenly thinking of other things and losing the intention of the breath, this is the sign of thoughts of calculation;
The bones and joints ache, unable to sit for a long time, this is the sign of overeating;
The body feels heavy and the mind is dull, only wanting to sleep, this is the sign of exhaustion;
Sitting in an inauspicious place, unable to breathe for a moment, this is the sign of an inauspicious place.
Knowing the fault, one should walk;
If one sits and reads the scriptures, the mind does not practice faults, and calamities will also be eliminated.
When a practitioner practices the Way, they should contemplate the basis.
What is the basis?
It refers to the mind, thought, and consciousness, which are the basis.
These three things are all unseen, and once arisen, they cease. The original intention does not arise again. Attaining this intention is the intention for the Way;
The original intention has already ceased, and without further causes and conditions, suffering is cut off.
Concentration and intention are mutually victorious, and mutual victory is concentration and intention.

Sometimes one attains concentration through the breath, sometimes through following, sometimes through stopping, and sometimes through contemplation. One should follow the causes and conditions for attaining concentration and practice straightforwardly.
Practicing the breath also falls into craving, why is it so?
Because the mind becomes joyful through concentration.
One should then contemplate the exhalation and inhalation of the breath, and when mindfulness ceases, the breath arises and the body arises;
When the breath ceases, the body ceases.
One has not yet escaped the suffering of birth and death, why is it so?
Having already contemplated joy, it is like this, and then craving ceases.
When counting breaths, one should be quick; when following, one should be slow.
Sometimes when counting breaths, one should be slow; when following, one should be quick.
Why is this?
When counting breaths, if the mind is not distracted, one should be slow; if distracted, one should be quick. Following is the same as this.
In the first, counting and following, the thoughts are different. Although counting breaths, one should know the exhalation and inhalation, and the mind is focused on counting.
After counting breaths, one practices following.
Stopping and contemplating means not attaining the breath;
In past lives, there were practices in following and stopping and contemplating.
Although attaining following, stopping and contemplating, one should still arise from counting breaths.
The mind not leaving counting breaths is the Dharma, not leaving, for counting breaths, the mind not following offenses, the mind in the world, then falling into offenses.
Counting breaths is for not wanting to disturb the mind. The mind, not disturbed, again practices following, verifying the previous mind, knowing stopping.
Stopping is the same as calming, and returning is the same as purifying.
If one attains a subtle understanding while practicing the Way, one should reverse the mind, meaning one should count the breath again.
If one has finished reading the sÅ«tras and then practices the subtle understanding of meditation, it means not counting the breath and not practicing the characteristics and following.
The Buddha has six pure intentions, namely counting the breath, following the breath, stopping, contemplating, returning, and purifying. These six things can control formlessness.
The breath is also the mind, but it is also not the mind.
Why is it so?
When counting, the mind is focused on the breath, so it is the mind.
When not counting, the mind and breath each function separately, so it is not the mind.
From the mind giving rise to the breath, stopping is without the intention of the mind.
People do not control the mind, the mind controls people.
Controlling the mind refers to counting the breath, following the breath, stopping, contemplating, returning, and purifying.
Recalling the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment is controlling the mind;
If a person does not practice the Way, greedily seeks after desires, this is called a person who is controlled by the mind.
Breath has defilements. If the defilements of the breath do not go away, one cannot obtain the breath.
What are the defilements of the breath?
It is the most severe of the three obscurations, which is called the defilements of the breath.
What are the three obscurations?
When the three poisons arise, the body is in the midst of darkness, so it is called the three obscurations.
The three poisons are:
1. Greed and lust, 2. Anger and hatred, 3. Ignorance and delusion.
People all die because of these three things, so they are called poisons.
When counting the breath, the mind is focused on counting the breath;
Before counting, there are three thoughts:
There are good thoughts, evil thoughts, and neither good nor evil thoughts.

If you want to know if a person has obtained the characteristics of the breath, you should observe myriad things and various beautiful colors, and if the mind no longer becomes attached, this is called obtaining the breath;
If the mind becomes attached again, this is called not having obtained it yet, and one should make further progress.
The mind that wishes to exhaust the household life refers to the six sense faculties as the mind's household, and craving for myriad things is all for the mind's household.
To follow means practicing wholesome dharmas, by which one attains liberation, and one should follow them;
it also means not following the five aggregates, six sense bases, breath, and mind.
Question:
Why is the third stillness placed at the tip of the nose?
Reply:

Because counting breaths, following, stillness, contemplation, returning, and purification all come and go from the nose, the mind is accustomed to it, and it is also easy to recognize, so it is placed at the tip of the nose.
When evil thoughts come, cut them off for meditation. Sometimes stillness is at the tip of the nose, sometimes stillness is in the heart;
wherever it is placed is stillness.
When evil comes to disturb the mind, directly contemplate one thing. When various evils come, the mind should not move. The mind is fearless.
There are four kinds of stillness:
The first is counting cessation, the second is following cessation, the third is nose-tip cessation, and the fourth is mind-cessation.
Cessation means the five desires and six sense-bases, which should be restrained and stopped.
Inhaling to the end at the nose-tip cessation means evil does not enter again to the nose-tip cessation;
Exhaling to the end attached to the nose-tip means the mind does not leave the body again to engage in evil, therefore attached to the nose-tip;
It also means when the breath first enters, it immediately turns towards not again, the inhalation and exhalation are also not felt again, this is cessation.
Cessation is like the exhalation and inhalation, aware of the previous intention to exhale, not aware of the subsequent intention to exhale.

Aware of the previous intention is the contemplation of the characteristics of the mind, then observing the inhalation and exhalation to see the decline, then accepting the characteristics of fear of birth and death, then withdrawing the mind, then following the characteristics of the mind of the path.

Do not let them follow each other, but only focus on the tip of the nose. Do not think of the causes and conditions of the five aggregates again. When the offenses are cut off and the mind is extinguished, and there is no more breathing, this is called cessation.
Do not let them follow each other means do not let the mind think of coming and going, following the causes and conditions of the five aggregates, and do not breathe again.
The fourth contemplation is to contemplate the decay of the breath, and to see the body and breath as different, arising from causes and conditions, and ceasing without causes and conditions.

The mind and intention receiving characteristics means when the mind intends to obtain something, the mind calculates that the causes and conditions will eventually cease again, and then cuts off the desires and does not pursue them. This is called the mind and intention receiving characteristics.

Using consciousness and causes and conditions as the characteristics of contemplation together means being conscious of the causes and conditions of the five aggregates, contemplating both the exhalation and inhalation of the breath;
Contemplation means contemplating the five aggregates, this is called the contemplation together.
One should also contemplate the mind and intention together, as the two causes and conditions, cutting off evil within and thinking of the Way.
Observing the difference between exhalation and inhalation means that exhalation is the aggregate of birth and death, and inhalation is the aggregate of thought;
Sometimes exhalation is the aggregate of pain and itchiness, and inhalation is the aggregate of consciousness.

Following the arising of conditions, one receives the aggregate of mental activities. The mind has no permanence in what it directs. For this reason, it is different. The practitioner should discern and know this.
This is also called the cessation of exhalation and the arising of inhalation;
The cessation of inhalation and the arising of exhalation.
As for non-existence, it refers to the human mind and myriad things. The mind arises and ceases, things are born and die again. This is called non-existence.
Exhalation is not inhalation, and inhalation is not exhalation;
It is not that when exhaling, the mind does not think of inhalation, and when inhaling, the mind does not think of exhalation. Because what is thought is different, it is said to be not.
As for middle faith, it refers to being in the middle of the path, seeing the causes and conditions of the path, and having faith in the path. This is called middle faith.
The fifth is the knot of abandonment, which means abandoning the seven evils of the body;
The sixth is the knot of pure abandonment, which is to abandon the three evils of the mind. This is called returning.
Returning means the mind no longer gives rise to evil;
Evil means not returning.
Returning the body means returning evil.
Having attained the fifth return, there is still the body, but also no body.
Why is this?
Having a mind and having a body, not having a mind and not having a body, the mind is the seed of a person. This is called returning.
Returning means the mind no longer gives rise to evil;
Giving rise to evil is not returning. It is also called assisting the body in the front and assisting the mind in the back.
Not killing, stealing, engaging in sexual misconduct, speaking divisively, speaking harshly, lying, and idle chatter are assisting the body;
Not being jealous, hateful, or deluded is assisting the mind.
Returning the five aggregates is like buying gold and getting a stone, then discarding it on the ground and not using it;
People all crave and love the five aggregates. When they obtain suffering and pain, they do not want them, which is returning to the five aggregates.
What is the place of the cessation of views? It is said that non-existence is the place of cessation.
Question:
Since there is already non-existence, why is it called a place?
The place of non-existence has four places:
First, flying birds take the sky as their place;
Second, arhats take nirvana as their place;
Third, the Way takes non-existence as its place;
Fourth, the Dharma is in the place of contemplation.

As for receiving the characteristics of the five aggregates through inhalation and exhalation, it means that the mind wrongly thinks, quickly turns back to the correct, and gives rise to awareness to cut off, which is receiving the characteristics of the five aggregates.
As for receiving, it means receiving the characteristics of acceptance and non-acceptance.
By receiving the characteristics of the five aggregates, know where they arise and where they cease.

As for cessation, it means receiving the twelve links of dependent origination. People are born from the twelve links of dependent origination and also die from the twelve links of dependent origination;
Not thinking refers to not thinking about the five skandhas.
Knowing what arises and what ceases means knowing that good and evil causes and conditions arise and then cease, also referring to the body, also referring to the arising and ceasing of qi.
Thinking gives rise to birth, not thinking gives rise to death. The mind and the body are equal, which is the way to cut off the path of birth and death.
Within this cycle of birth and death, all evil things come from the mind.

What is done now is not done by the past, and what was done in the past is not done by the present. This means that what was thought in the past has already ceased, and the present thought is not the past thought;
It also means that what is done in this life and what was done in the past life each have their own blessings;
It also means that the good done now is not the evil done in the past;
It also means that the breath now is not the breath of the past, and the breath of the past is not the breath of the present.
As for distinguishing birth and death, it means that when the mind thinks of birth, it is born, and when it thinks of cessation, it ceases.
Therefore, it is said that birth and death should distinguish myriad things and the body.
The blessings of the past and future are sought to be exhausted.
Why is it so?
Because when there is birth, there is immediately extinction, and when there is extinction, there is immediately exhaustion;
Having already known exhaustion, one should exhaust one's strength in seeking it.
Looking above the head, there is no place from which one comes, meaning that people do not come from anywhere, and the mind arises to become a person;
It is also said that people do not come from anywhere because they have a place from which they come;
People create themselves and obtain themselves, this is called having no place from which they come.
As for the distinction between life and death, it means knowing the distinction between the five skandhas, and also knowing the distinction between the mind and life and death.

The human mind is considered to be eternal, but knowing that it is not eternal is also a distinction.ğŸ”½Looking at the end without a place, it means that in the present one does not see sinners in life and death, but will certainly attain it, because there is no escape from sin.

It is said that looking at the end there is no place, those who have not attained the trace of the Way cannot obtain it in the middle of their lives, it is said that those who have already attained the fifteen [stages] cannot die in the middle;
If one attains fifteen, one's mind will fall into the Way, and one will also progress to become an arhat.

If one attains the Way in the middle, one will not die in the middle. The mind, breath, and body are three things. If one has a good or evil mind, one must attain the Way, and one will also be destroyed in the middle;
If one dies while breathing, one's good mind will arise and then cease, and one's body will also not die in the middle.
What is purity?
It is said that all that is greedily desired is impure, and removing greed is purity.
What are the characteristics of the five aggregates?
It is said that fire is an aggregate, and firewood is its characteristic.
From breath to purity, these are all contemplations;
It is said that contemplating the characteristics of the body, following, stopping, contemplating, returning, and purifying, are originally non-existent.
Counting the breath internally and externally, and externally cutting off evil causes and conditions, these are the two minds.
Question:
Why not first internally and externally contemplate the body, but rather first count the breath, follow, stop, contemplate, return, and purify?
Answer:
Because the mind is impure, one does not see it. When the body and mind are already pure, one then sees both inside and outside the body.
There are nineteen practices, because people have nineteen illnesses, and there are also nineteen medicines.
Contemplating the body as impure is the medicine for stopping lust.
Contemplating the four immeasurable minds is the medicine for stopping anger.
Reflecting on one's own past causes and conditions is the medicine for stopping delusion.
Mindfulness of breathing is the medicine for excessive thoughts.
Contemplate the body internally and externally.
What is the body?
What is the essence?
Bones and flesh are the body, and the six sense faculties combined are the essence.
What are the six sense faculties?

They are the eyes perceiving forms, the ears receiving sounds, the nose smelling fragrances, the mouth desiring flavors, the body feeling smoothness, and the mind's faculties being the seeds, planted by ignorance, leading to the existence of living beings.
Why is the internal and external body mentioned again?
It means that people's greed and seeking have degrees of magnitude, and there is a sequence.
It means that what one desires to obtain should be discerned and contemplated. The contemplator sees it as mindfulness, and mindfulness is based on seeing. The contemplator is aware of it.

The contemplation of the body means sitting in meditation and giving rise to thoughts. When thoughts arise, the mind does not depart. The mind is attached to what it experiences, which is called consciousness. This is the contemplation of the body.
When the mindfulness of inhalation and exhalation ceases, what is the time of the cessation of mindfulness?
It means when the inhalation and exhalation of breath cease, the mind also ceases.
When the mindfulness of inhalation and exhalation ceases, it is like drawing in empty space. There is no place of birth and death. The mind and the path are the same.
When the mindfulness of inhalation and exhalation ceases, it is also not said that the breath ceases. When the mind of breath ceases, it is said to cease.
When the mindfulness of inhalation and exhalation ceases, things arise from causes and conditions. When the root is cut off, it is the time of cessation.
The contemplation of seeing internal and external feelings means seeing where feelings arise, and then contemplating them. This is the contemplation of seeing.
As for internal and external pain and itchiness, external good things are external itchiness, and external bad things are external pain;
internal pleasant things are internal itchiness, and internal unpleasant things are internal pain.
What is inside is internal dharmas, and external conditions are external dharmas;
it is also said that the eyes are internal, and forms are external;
the ears are internal, and sounds are external;
the nose is internal, and smells are external;
the mouth is internal, and tastes are external;
the mind is internal, and thoughts are external.
Seeing good and smooth things, wanting to obtain them, is itchiness;
seeing coarse and evil things, not wanting them, is pain.
Both fall into offenses.

As for the cessation of observing pain and itchiness, if a person's arm hurts, the mind does not think of pain, but rather thinks of the pain in the entire body of others like this, using the mind not to be in pain, it is the cessation of pain;
it can be thought of, and it cannot be thought of, thinking of pain without attachment.
Loving one's own body, one should observe the bodies of others;
If one loves others' bodies, one should observe one's own body, and this is also a means of stopping [desire].
Why are internal and external feelings mentioned twice?
It is said that when people see forms, their love has varying degrees, and their minds do not equally observe, as there are differences between many and few.
Therefore, the path of observation is repeatedly distinguished. One should internally observe delusion and externally observe to realize oneself.
Physical and mental feelings are each different. Experiencing cold, heat, blows, and pain is physical pain;
Experiencing delicious food, carriages, fine clothes, and bodily comforts is physical itching.
Mental pain is when one worries about oneself, worries about others and myriad things, this is mental pain;
When the mind obtains what it likes and various joys, this is mental itching.
The observation of the mind has two causes and conditions, which internally sever evil thoughts and the path [to enlightenment].
First, it is said that the five desires and six decays should be controlled and severed.
When observing, one observes one's own body. The body does not know coarseness or subtlety. Only when one attains it does one become aware. This is the mutual observation of mind and mind.
The mutual observation of mind and mind, the breath is also mind, and counting is also mind;
When counting, observing the breath is the mutual observation of mind and mind.

The observation of cessation of mind refers to restraining desire and lust, not being angry due to anger, not being deluded due to delusion, not seeking various evil things due to greed, not turning towards anything. This is called observation and cessation;
It is also called knowing the Sutra of the Thirty-Seven Factors of Enlightenment, always mindful and not apart, as cessation.
The observation of the complete cessation of exhalation and inhalation refers to the complete cessation of offenses and the cessation of the mind.
Complete observation refers to the observation of cessation and return to purity;
Complete cessation refers to being able to explain this, understand this, and thoroughly understand this. This is called complete cessation.
If the breath that arises gives rise to generosity, making merit, and all wholesome dharmas, and after arising it ceases, does the mind think of it again?
The practice of past and present sins is also countless, and the mind does not follow such appearances;
Others are also like this. Having known and perceived, one should cut off what has already been cut off, which is the cessation of contemplation of the internal and external mind.
As for the dharmas of internal and external phenomena, internal phenomena refer to the body, and external phenomena refer to other people;
There are dharmas of upholding precepts and dharmas of not upholding precepts, which are the dharmas of internal and external phenomena.

Internal phenomena refer to practicing wisdom without leaving the Sutra of the Thirty-Seven Factors of Enlightenment, and the mind does not fall into any other matters. Practicing the Way and attaining the Way are internal phenomena.
External phenomena refer to falling into birth and death, which is to say the practice of birth and death, and thus attaining birth and death.
Not being liberated from all, one should cut off what has already been cut off, which is the cessation of contemplation of internal and external phenomena.
As for the contemplation of dharmas and stillness, all people take their own body as their body, but carefully contemplate that it is not their body.
Why is it so?
There is the eye and there is form, but the eye is also not the body, and form is also not the body.
Why is it so?
When a person has already died, there is the eye but nothing to see, and there is form but nothing to correspond with.
The body is like this, it only has consciousness but is also not the body.
Why is it so?

Consciousness has no form and also has no weight or location, contemplating the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind in this way is also like this, attaining this contemplation is called the contemplation of dharmas, and it is also called the stillness of not thinking of evil.
Thinking of evil is not stillness, why is it so?
